Award.AwardTitle: Harnessing room-temperature quantum-dot-like states in 2D materials for nanoscale non-classical light sources
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Summary
Light-based quantum technologies rely on the creation and manipulation of individual photons, the discrete fundamental packets of energy that constitute light. Engineers and scientists who are seeking to use light for quantum technologies require “single-photon emitter” devices that produce just a single photon with a flip of a switch. Such devices, however, need single-photon emitting materials that are hard to come by because they also need to be compatible with modern semiconductor engineering and fabrication techniques. Recently, a new class of single-photon emitters was discovered in ultrathin two-dimensional materials and was greeted with much excitement because, among other advantages, two-dimensional materials can be more easily integrated into devices than most other single-photon emitting materials. However, the underlying material properties and physical phenomena that lead to the single-photon emission in two-dimensional materials remain unknown: it is known that single-photon emitters exist, but it is not known why. This project aims to answer this critical question by combining highly sophisticated optical microscopy techniques to study single-photon emitters in two-dimensional materials on ultrasmall length scales. The experimental studies are complemented by the development of theoretical models to better predict their behavior and identify ways to improve their performance for quantum technologies. These research activities include strong components of quantum-centered education and workforce training, including highly interdisciplinary Ph.D. research, integrated undergraduate research opportunities, curriculum development, and public and K-12 outreach activities.

Technical Summary
Light-based quantum technologies necessitate quantum emitters to produce single photons or entangled photon pairs on demand. The discovery of single-photon emitters (SPEs) in monolayer WSe2 (1L-WSe2) ushered in a revolutionary class of solid-state quantum emitters with new opportunities for deterministic positioning, facile emitter control, and integrability into photonic architectures. However, the physical mechanisms giving rise to these promising states are still unknown, hindering their development. Using state-of-the-art theoretical modeling with advanced experimental characterization, a new mechanism of strain-induced exciton localization in 1L-WSe2 was previously identified. It upends the understanding of strain localization of excitons in two-dimensional semiconductors and may be the mechanism that underlies many SPEs in 1L-WSe2. With an overarching goal of developing an understanding of SPE phenomena in 1L-WSe2 that will guide their development into controllable quantum photonic devices, this project is focused on (1) investigating whether the newly discovered states are room-temperature SPEs; (2) establishing the roles of these states in known low-temperature SPEs; and (3) exploring new routes for engineering the creation and active control of SPEs in 1L-WSe2 and other two-dimensional materials. The research strategy combines nano-optical characterization with low-temperature quantum optical measurements and theory, and it is integrated with educational efforts emphasizing mentoring and hands-on learning about photonic materials, quantum optical characterization techniques, and the fundamentals of quantum information science for students in high school through graduate school.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: This project investigated generating single photons of light, which are the fundamental quantum states of light from two-dimensional (2D) semiconductors for use in quantum technologies. The laws of quantum mechanics describe the fundamental behavior of microscopic systems that make up the world around us. Quantum technologies seek to exploit these laws and behaviors to achieve groundbreaking advances in computing, communications, and sensing. Many potential quantum technology platforms either rely on or would strongly benefit from using single photons of light to create, process, and/or transport quantum-compatible information. However, a major technological challenge is to generate single photons of light at a specific time from a device that operates at room temperature. Existing solutions are not ideal and generate single photons of light at random instances of time and/or require ultracold temperatures near absolute zero. Atomically thin 2D semiconducting materials offer the potential to overcome these limitations, but a system with ideal properties such as elevated operating temperatures, uniform quantum light source properties, and maximum brightness still has not been developed.

From the project, a new light generation system was fabricated by stretching 2D semiconductors over arrays of nanoscale-sized cones. The stretching of the 2D semiconductor is very important because it creates ultramicroscopic regions of strain in the material that produce quantum states of light. The advantage of the system developed in this project is that the strain can be carefully controlled by the structure of the nanocone array and the region of strain can be shrunk to smaller sizes, which is important for device miniaturization. In addition to demonstrating the ability to control these microscopic regions of strain and that they generate quantum states of light, we performed detailed studies that compared their properties of quantum light generation to other systems based on atomically thin 2D semiconductors. The quantum light sources of this project were shown to be brighter and have more uniform properties than the other systems. The project also performed joint studies that characterized the quantum light emission and nanoscale structure of the local regions of strain on the same sample.  These joint studies revealed that while the new methodology of creating nanowrinkles creates a new class of more homogenous quantum light sources in the 2D semiconductors, controlling other microscopic properties of the light sources such as their polarization and color requires even finer control of the localized strain, setting the stage for future nanoengineering efforts of these promising light sources.

Beyond single quantum states of light, this project also investigated the creation of quantum pairs of photons of light. Generating such pairs of photons from a material is a complex process and is typically very inefficient. The studies of this project discovered that the efficiency of the pair generation process can be increased by injecting more energy into the 2D semiconductor material. This discovery is under deeper ongoing investigations by the project team and others to develop a theoretical model that can describe the observed enhancement.

Broader impacts: The project trained two Ph.D. scientists in Mechanical Engineering and Physics. In addition, the project contributed to the training of 7 undergraduate students and 6 masters students by providing them with research experience related to the project. The leaders of the project integrated the scientific achievements into educational materials at the high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels. Instructional units on quantum technologies, the use of light in quantum technologies, nanoscale mechanical engineering of materials, and nanoscale light-matter interactions have been developed and are in use in courses at the institutions where the project was conducted.
